newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatia's cenbank cuts interest on liquidity bills.
newsitem.headline: Croatia's cenbank cuts interest on liquidity bills.

text.p: Croatia's central bank cut the interest paid on its liquidity bills on Wednesday, in what it said was a logical step to follow trimming of the official rates.
It declined to say whether it had signalled investors -- commercial banks -- to put in bids at lower rates for the paper sold weekly to mop up excess kuna from the banking system.
The central bank plans no other operations on the money market this week, an official told Reuters.
The 35-day 35- and 91-day rates were cut by 50 basis points to 7.0 and 8.50 percent, respectively at the regular auction.
Bill volume rose slightly to 92 million kuna on an average 470 million on the banks' balances this week. Clients can view full auction results on page NBHT.
The banking sector liquidity was bolstered after the central bank broght the reserve requirement down to under 35 percent on kuna deposits, effective from April.
In March it cut the discount rate to 5.9 from 6.5 percent previusly and the Lombard emergency lending rate for banks to 9.5 percent from 11.
The central bank envisages further easing of its monetary policy this year in a bid to help the economy. -- Kolumbina Bencevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
